After reverend gentleman said the opinion of the Talmud, he
expressed his view about it:

The chief precept of our Religion is: to be holy, that
is: so love God, for this is holiness. Inferior so this
precept is: to acknowledge God, expressed in the first command
ment of the revelation. If we acknowledge God, we love him
and are holy. Our Holy Thora is the guide to the summit
of this divine Dea?. Philanthropy, kindness and mercy to every
creature both living and lifeless, rectitude for the whole human
race, a powerful dominion above ourselves as well as above nature are
the ways, which our Thora teaches us, to acknowledge the invisible
Deity by his divine attributes. Be as kind and mercyful as our
Thora will it, thus Gods benevolence is displayed unto you &
but who total you will never acknowledge him ודהו שומע תפילה וגו'
But yet a way shows no us our Thora to aim this holy end, and this
way is the prayer, and therefore is it the most perfect services

because it guides directly to acknowledging of God, as our
Thora said: ברכות לב לעולם יסדר אדם שבחו של הקב"ה ואח"כ יתפלל
(איפא פנימיו אומר אם תפילה של אדם נשמעת אלא בבית הכנסת שנאמר לשמוע אל הרנה ואל) If our prayers be Hymns and praises, the
subjective effect is a direct display of God's divine character
but if our prayers are supplanting or reporting our own foo-
lishness or weekness are the direct, and God's omnipotence and
mercy the indirect display. Therefore hymns are the former
and prayers the latter part of our service.

b If the effect of prayer is subjective, we want in them
no mediation between God and man, neither of the angels nor
of other spiritual beings.

This is the sublime character of our Religion, displaying
us the purest and most perfect notion of God, of the features
of his holy existence; guiding us the way to his perfection,
she also represents us the possible perfection of man by
the precepts of the revelation, for only to his likeness can
God speak; by the precepts. In the Likeness of God in his own
image the man was created, sons are you to the Living God,
our holy doctrine taught us the perfection of the human ?
that the man is the next intellectual being to God, he is his
son, that he can acknowledge God and serve him without one
mediation. No religion in the whole world possesses those high
terms of truth, trust and eternal hopes. The Psalmist was
inspired by those Deas and sung so lovely ראשונה כפי סברת המוני והוא השגת תכלית מבוקשו, אך אתן שינוי לבתי אדון כל.
But those high notions make us very easily proud or haughty,
therefore we need to be remined of our foolishness, meekness,
transitoriness, invalidity and nullity, that shall be done
by our prayers of supplication and repentence, and not
by the notion of the mediation (that was the first reason of it)
for this is an Sea guise strangely to our holy Religion.

C If the effect of our prayers shall be subjective, our
service ought to be in the hebrew language—for
this language is the tongue of our Prophets, of our
solemn Psalmists, the tongue of our holy scripture.
yea, the mere soun of those words awake our heart
to a holier feeling and higher inspiration, to a
sublime admiration of the most High. There exists no
language, that possesses a character so sublime and ador
ing, simple and short, easy and living, this is the
best vehicle of our thoughts before God. And again,
no poetry had so aft and manifold the Deity to her
object, nor sung so solemnly the attributes and perfections
of God, as the hebrew did; there is no poetry possessing
those riches of natural picturesque and scenery, which breath
love and admiration in the heart. Those sentimental
sentim sentences of the prophets, those conserated and deeply
felt words of the holy Scripture are the best vehicle ?
to adore our God. And again we ought to understand the
words of our heart, and where is the son of Israel, who
understands not the language of his Thora? If some
should be so unhappy to be ignorant in the word of his

I am yours

Perhaps you can find place for those lines
in your Journal of this month.
Dear Sir!

I recommend to you my agent
Mr. M. Light, who is authorized to collect
agents of subscribers for the History of the
Israelitish Nation, and wish you to recommend
him to your friends.

I shall continue to write on the Jurisprudence
of the Israelites, and afterwards republish it in
pamphlet form. If you have to make to me any
remarks on this subject I shall be pleased to read
of you.

Please to give my best respects to your
mother.
Respectfully yours
Dear Sir!

Being in possession of your
favor of the 12. inst., I am sorry that I
cannot serve you; as usually I have not preserved
the articles on Jurisprudence. I am very lazy in
this respect.

Please to inform the judge, that he can find
a historical development of the subject in the
appendices to each period of my “History &c,
which will be continued in each of the following
volumes.

I took the liberty of sending to you ten copies
of the first volume of my History to supply
you and your friends; since I cannot immediately
send an agent to distribute them.

Please deposit some copies in a bookstore which
you think most fit together with one of the
annexed circulars. I sell to bookstores for
$1,50 per copy.
Most Respectfully
Yours
Albany December 14: 1853.

You find the best account about the school of Padua in
Dr. I. M Josts ?

while the former book contains an authentical and perfect

1350 be the date of its foundation I have to observe, that

Were I not too much employed otherwise I would fur
nish you with a sketch; but I think it is too interesting

You will be kind enough to excuse me, that I would not

?; I was rejected, abused wherever I opened the door;
I found that men as Mr. Isaac, Mr. Lyon, Mr. Rosen-

the prayers and humbug the world with an assumed

I hope to give to the world a history of our nation, which
will fully show the important position of Israel among the
nations. You see, my dear sir, that I did not yet think how
to publish it, as I was not sure of success; but now I
have made my plan to this effect. As soon as the number
of subscribers is important enough, I shall publish the
first volume reaching to the destruction of the first
temple. I shall first offer the business to Mr. Hart of
Philadelphia; because he, being an Israelite, feels more in?
in the matter than other publishers. If we cannot agree
on the terms for I have about $1500,00 expenses for books
necessary to the purpose—then I thought of going to Harpen
or another publisher. If I can agree with none I publish
it myself for my subscribers only; for them, after the work
will be completed, I am sure every publisher will buy the
copy right. It will remain a standard work for the next
25 years. This is my intention, and I see in your letter,
it will meet with your approbation.

I wish, you would be kind enough, to let me have your
corrections on the Jurisprudence of the Israelites.
Please to accept of my assurance of my best respect.
Truly Yours
Albany, March 25. 1853
To John Samuel Esq. Philadelphia
Dear Sir

Your favor of the 24. inst. was duely received, and
I take of this early opportunity to thank you for your kindness
which you manifest in the interest taken in my intended
publication. Permit me, dear sir, to give you a short
history of my history, and you will find, that your
suggestions are really welcome to me.

I felt for years the necessity of having a complete and
unfalsified account of our nation in the English language,
wherefore I commenced translating Jost's history of the
Israelites; after I was done nearly half with the work
I notified my attention to the public; but the opposition
against this work was great both here and in Germany.
Dr. Frankel of Dresden, and Dr. Sachs of Berlin, as
well as Dr. Raphael of New York and others were
greatly opposed to the work; because, they say, Dr. Jost
did not write in the interest of Jews, but to obtain a
professorship. I know this, but I had not the moral
courage to undertake the composition of an original
work. My friends in Germany, and especially Dr.
Frankel urged the matter upon me; my friends here also
